object.content:
Dalai Lama Quote of the Week

When we achieve a mind focused on mind with the perfect placement of absorbed concentration, free from all faults of dullness or flightiness, we increasingly experience an element of bliss accompanying our meditation. When we experience serene joy, on both a physical and mental level, brought on by the force of total absorption of mind on mind, we achieve a meditational state that fulfills the definition of shamata.

Our ordinary mind is like raw iron ore that needs to be made into a steel sword. Progressing through the stages for attaining shamata is like forging the iron into steel. All the materials are there at our disposal. But since the mind wanders after external objects, then although it is the material for attaining shamata, it cannot yet be used as this product. We have to forge our mind through a meditational process. It is like putting the iron ore into fire.

To fashion the steel into a sword, or in this analogy to fashion the mind into an instrument that understands voidness, our serenely stilled and settled mind needs to come to decisive realization of voidness as its object. Without such a weapon of mind, we have no opponent with which to destroy the disturbing emotions and attitudes.(p.142)

--from The Gelug/Kagyu Tradition of Mahamudra by H.H. the Dalai Lama and Alexander Berzin, published by Snow Lion Publications

I don't understand Mahamudra with impermanence. I understand Mahamudra to be the nature of mind, the changeless nature, Not too dissimilar to Buddha Nature or enlightened potential. How can the nature of mind be changeless when everything is said to be impermanent and devoid of self existence?

+Albert Tremblay I doubt anybody can understand Mahamudra on intellectual level and Buddha Nature is so huge and difficult topic to digest itself (at least for me, much more than i.e. emptiness) that I cannot say a word about the comparison of two. But imho Nature of Mind simply cannot be impermanent because it is not created and at the same time it is empty of any inherent existence. "Simply put", any phenomena can be either absolute or existing, not both. Absolute means not created and existing means impermanent. Please anybody correct me if I am wrong.

Hi Jaroslav and Richard,

Mahamudra is the essence of mind, and it is accepted by the four schools of buddhism. How can the nature of mind exist if everything is impermanent?

At some point you have to look at what is meant by impermenant. Is impermenance impermenant? No, all is impermanent, everything that is of composite nature.

There is the paradox. Experience is relative, therefore the basis has to be absolute. In order for anything to exist, everything impermanent, nothing has to exist to form it's basis.

My favorite way to define Buddha Nature is the potential to become enlightened. This is really off the top of my head, I have just scratched the surface myself.

Thanks for the words,
May this merit alleviate the suffering of beings
